parse.title: Song of the Ent and Entwife

links.*: A Closed Letter to Andrea Charicoryides Surnamed Polygrapheus, Logothete of the Theme of Geodesia in the Empire, Bard of the Court of Camelot, Malleus Malitiarium, Inclinga Sum Sometimes Known as Charles Williams
A Fragment of an Epic: Before Jerusalem Richard Makes an End of Speech
Adventures in Unnatural History and Medieval Metres, being the Freaks of Fisiologus
Bilbo's Last Song (at the Grey Havens)
Chip the glasses and crack the plates!
Cold be hand and heart and bone,
Dark Are the Clouds about the North
Far over the misty mountains cold
Farewell We Call to Hearth and Hall!
From dark Dunharrow in the dim morning
Hey dol! merry dol! ring a dong dillo!
Hop along, my little friends, up the Withywindle!
I Sit beside the Fire and Think
In Western Lands beneath the Sun
Lemminkainen Goeth to the Fords of Oxen
Over Old Hills and Far Away
Over the land there lies a long shadow
Poems in The Lord of the Rings
Seek for the Sword that was broken
Sir Gawain and the Green Knight
Song of the Mounds of Mundburg
Tha Eadigan Saelidan: The Happy Mariners
The Battle of the Eastern Field
The Chronology of The Lord of the Rings
The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien
The Complaint of Mîm the Dwarf
The Homecoming of Beorhtnoth Beorhthelm's Son
The Last of the Old Gods
The Lay of Aotrou and Itroun
The Lay of the Children of Húrin
The Lay of the Fall of Gondolin
The Lion Is Loud and Proud
The Little House of Lost Play: Mar Vanwa Tyaliéva
The Lord of the Rings (1981 radio series)
The Man in the Moon Came Down Too Soon
The Man in the Moon Stayed Up Too Late
The Swallow, and the Traveller on the Plains
The wind was on the withered heath
The world was young, the mountains green,
Twenty years have flowed away down the long river
Under the mountain dark and tall
When winter first begins to bite
Where now the horse and the rider? Where is the horn that was blowing?
The Mermaid's Flute from 'The Lay of Earendel'
The Horns of the Host of Doriath
An Ode Inspired by Intimations of the Approach of Early Morning Tea
Ye laggard woodlands and ye slumbrous brakes
I stood upon an empty shore before the sun was born
A Rhyme Royal upon Easter Morning
Moonshine: Verses in a Medieval Measure
Lines Composed in a Village Inn on an Evening of Extraordinary Liquid Beauty
The Tale of Beewolf Son of Echgethew
Völsungakviða en nýja eða Sigurðarkviða en mesta
Guðrúnarkviða en nýja eða Dráp Niflunga
Hit was an olde mon fro Pimbilmere
When little Louis came to stay
Though all things fail & come to naught,
My heart is not in this land where I live:
'At last the time has come,' he said,

wikitext.*:
{{unnamed}} {{poem infobox | title="''The Song of the Ent and the Entwife''" | image= | caption= | imageWidth= | imageHeight= | other names="Of the Ents and Entwives" | written=Late [[1941]] or early [[1942]] | revised= | published=''[[The Two Towers]]'',
''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]'' | subject=[[Search of the Ents]] }} "'''''The Song of the Ent and the Entwife'''''"{{TI|XXII}}, p. 421 (note 10) is a poem recited to [[Meriadoc Brandybuck]] and [[Peregrin Took]] by [[Treebeard]], concerning the longing of the [[Ents]] for their lost [[Entwives]].{{TT|III4}} ==Poem excerpts== Ent: When spring unfolds the beechen-leaf and sap is in the bough, When light is on the wild-wood stream, and wind is on the brow, When stride is long, and breath is deep, and keen the mountain air, Come back to me! Come back to me, and say my land is fair! ''Entwife:'' When Spring is come to garth and field, and corn is in the blade, When blossom like a shining snow is on the orchard laid, When sun and shower upon the earth with fragrance fill the air, I'll linger here, and will not come, because my land is fair! ''Both:'' Together we will take the road that leads into the West, And far away will find a land where both our hearts may rest. ==History== After the loss of the [[Entwives]] and their [[Brown Lands|gardens]] during the [[War of the Last Alliance]]{{L|144}} in the late [[Second Age]], the [[Ents]] began a long search for them. Afterwards, the [[Search of the Ents]] became the subject of many [[Elvish]] songs; some of which were translated into the many [[Mannish|languages]] of [[Men]]. One such song, which the Ents remembered orally, "used to be sung up and down the [[Anduin|Great River]]" according to [[Treebeard]]. This song took the form of a dialogue between an Ent and an Entwife and mentioned a prophecy foretelling that they will find a land where they both can be happy together after both have lost everything. On Tuesday''[[The Chronology of The Lord of the Rings]]'', "[Others of Company]", p. 56 of [[29 February]] in the year {{TA|3019}} during the late [[Third Age]],{{App|B3}}, entry for 29 February [[Treebeard]] recited the song to [[Meriadoc Brandybuck]] and [[Peregrin Took]] in [[Fangorn Forest]] after they asked what had happened to them. ==Background== In late [[1941]] or early [[1942]],{{CP|165}} [[J.R.R. Tolkien]] made "four pages" of "rough workings" for the poem in a manuscript with the words "[?Of] the Ents and Entwives".{{TI|XXII}}, pg. 418 Tolkien wrote the "first completed draft" of the poem on the fifth page of the manuscript. In this manuscript, the first and third stanzas were already in the form of the published text, the sixth stanza differed "only in the first line", and the ending mentions the Ents finding the Entwives "in the rain" and together going "to an island" where they can both be happy. [[Christopher Tolkien]] refers to the poem as "the Song of the Ent and the Entwife" at one point. The italicized name ''The Song of the Ent and the Entwife'' appears in the note where the first completed draft appears, but it is unknown whether Tolkien wrote that name on the draft or whether [[Christopher Tolkien]] wrote the name on the note. Tolkien added speakers for each stanza in a second draft before revising the poem to its published form for "the first typescript of the chapter" it would appear in. In [[August]] of [[1952]], Tolkien made a recording of the song amongst other poems he recorded. In response to a question from fr. Douglas Carter, Tolkien remarked in a letter on [[6 June]] in [[1972]] that the song might be evidence "that there would be no re-union in 'history'" between the Ents and the Entwives.{{L|338}} In the [[2008]] essay, "The Myth of the Ent and the Entwife", [[Corey Olsen]] speculated that the song was composed by an Elf who did not hold any bias towards either side, managing to convey multiple meanings "through the layering of the two voices".{{TS|5}}, pp. 39-53 While Tolkien never wrote a composition to accompany the song, several fans have made renditions. One version is the work of Bart Zeal entitled "[http://youtu.be/4pxfoJs0aPQ The Epic of The Ent & The Entwife]" while another version is sung by Clamavi De Profundis entitled "[http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NNL8zG0hsB0 The Ent and the Ent-Wife]". In [[2024]], the song was included as entry 165 in ''[[The Collected Poems of J.R.R. Tolkien]]''. In their commentary, [[Wayne G. Hammond]] and [[Christina Scull]] mention that the poem is often referred to as the "Song of the Ent and the Entwife". ==Portrayal in adaptations== '''1981: [[The Lord of the Rings (1981 radio series)|''The Lord of the Rings'' (1981 radio series)]]:''' :Treebeard sings a part on the song aloud while on his way to [[Entmoot]]. ==See also== * [[Poems in The Lord of the Rings|Poems in ''The Lord of the Rings'']] {{references}} {{poems}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Song of the Ent and the Entwife, The}} [[Category:Poems in The Two Towers]]
